channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-3569] Performance regression in PDColorSpace#toRGBImageAWT
item.description:
I've a private pdf containing 1900 tiny inline images (CMYK, 8bit) which renders way too slow. Again the CMYK2RGB conversion is the culprit here, BUT the known issue with the KCMS/LCMS change isn't the main problem here.

I ran some tests on linux (PDFToImage time -imageType png -resolution 150)
1.6.0_37: 355s
1.7.0_25: 289s
1.7.0_75: 298s
1.8.0_101: cancelled after 15 min

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I've replaced the ColorConvertOp.filter with a pixel by pixel conversion and the rendering is down to 3s.

tilman Please check the attached patch using your testarena.
Updated patch
There are many, many slight differences... for example, PDFBOX-1058 p.3, bottom left "lcd screen", top right, and "go green". Also PDFBOX-2700-JCS_YCCK.pdf. I'll attach some.
old files first... so they should appear grey after I upload the new renderings.

Also page 3 of PDFBOX-2348. That one has an ICC colorspace but CMYK is used. I mention this file because with the other files, maybe the colors are the result of some more processing (masks, transparencies etc)
Also the reference images in GWG060_Shading_x1a.pdf and GWG061_Shading_x1a.pdf
It's the same... you just fixed the imports (which I did as well).

tilman Thanks for the fast response. I'll have a close look.

Meanwhile I've ran some tests on my virtual win7 and my patch is only 6x faster than the current implementation, using 1.7.0_21 (on linux it's about 100x faster). It looks like the windows version of the jvm isn't that bad. BTW, my colleague who reported the regression renders on AIX and it took hours up to days to render the pdf depending on the jvm.

ColorConvertOp.filter is able to take advantage of hardware acceleration and was chosen because it was by far the fastest approach. What's changed?

Note that if you're testing on VMs or AIX JVMs you're presumably not going to get any hardware acceleration, so these may be meaningless comparisons.

ColorConvertOp.filter is able to take advantage of hardware acceleration and was chosen because it was by far the fastest approach. What's changed?

I never ran any speed tests for such cases until now. Obviously there is no hardware acceleration in my cases (Linux native, Win7 VM and AIX). Furthermore the gap wasn't that big if only one or just a few images are involved so that nobody cared about that. But in my special case (1900 tiny inline images on one page) that gap grows to a big difference.

Note that if you're testing on VMs or AIX JVMs you're presumably not going to get any hardware acceleration, so these may be meaningless comparisons.

I've never intended to compare the end results of different platforms/enviroment, but IMHO it is interesting that the releative acceleration by my patch differs a lot.
I've expected that. Some differences are more or less invisible but the old implementation delivers mostly/always better results.
I wonder how it compares on a system with hardware acceleration, if there is a difference or not?
Maybe make it configurable for users who run their software in "the cloud"?
Or is there an API which allows us to detect if hardware acceleration is available?
The classes in sun.java2d.cmm doesn't provide such an information

I'm going to make it configurable.

Any ideas for a name to be used as parameter?

  • org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.UsePureJavaCMYKConversion
Surely this problem will apply to any ICCBased color space too, not just DeviceCMYK?

I've attached a new version of the patch

  • use a two step conversion to eliminate differences compared to the icc profile conversion
  • implemented the usage of the parameter "usePureJavaCMYKConversion" to activate the new conversion method
Yes the results are much better. There are some invisible differences, and only one slightly visible difference for file gs-bugzilla692845.pdf .

I've just followed a hint in the javadoc of ColorSpace#toRGB to use a 2 step conversion (CMYK -> CIEXYZ -> RGB), it wasn't my ingenius idea.

Im goint to run some more performance test to shed some light on the hardware acceleration thing.

Commit 1772528 from lehmi in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1772528 ]

PDFBOX-3569: added a pure java CMYK2RGB conversion due to a performance regression when using ColorConvertOp.filter

Commit 1772529 from lehmi in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1772529 ]

PDFBOX-3569: added a pure java CMYK2RGB conversion due to a performance regression when using ColorConvertOp.filter
We'd need some documentation about this, e.g. in the FAQ.

I'd go for documenting it in the Javadoc and the release notes. Maybe we start having some more information in the notes for notable changes similar to what we did for moving from 1.8.x to 2.0.0 (Migration Guide) What we could do is start documenting these changes as we develop a new release so it's a living document and as soon as the release is done the document will be stable. For changes which need some more explanation we could also have a small article visible in the blog section of the website. WDYT?
I never read release notes. My thought is that somebody uses PDFBox and it's suddenly very slow for some files. Such a person would probably search in google or stackoverflow and maybe the website.
Can you print a message if it takes too long using old method?
How would be decide what is "too long"? It depends on the computer, the java version, the image size and who knows what else.

the notes would be available on the website highlighting major changes and notices per release similar to the current migration guide. Of course we can add to the FAQ but would need to mention from which release on the information is valid and/or invalid.
Yes, agreed.

I tried this patch and it did not improve performance at all. On the contrary actually. I have PDF files from a newspaper, one PDF per page and I am rendering those to JPEG images. This is slow regardless of if I am using the patch or not. And I have set the Kodac CMS also.
20 pages of these pages takes about 90 seconds without patch, and about 650 seconds with patch. So no go with these PDF files. The PDF files are for print with high quality CMYK images. They need to be rendered as RGB. I'm on Pdfbox 2.0.3

I've tried on both Windows (my desktop computer) and a virtual Linux in Amazon EC2 which has no graphics card. The results where the same. The patch is way slower.

I will attach a sample PDF to this issue. (UNTUNT-*.pdf). Any hints on how to speed up rendering is appreciated,
PDF file that is slower with patch
No CMYK there.
New sample with CMYK images

Sorry, seems to have added the only page without CMYK images in it.
Replaced sample with a new one.

Actually, I don't know if the images are CMYK, but I do get to the toRGBImageAWT()method repeatedly that is patched and causes slowdowns. So I assumed that they are cmyk.

I ran some tests. I've rendered GWG060_Shading_x1a.pdf , GWG061_Shading_x1a.pdf and PDFBOX1058-DocuPrintMono205Series_8c68.pdf using 

PDFToImage -time -imageType png -resolution 300

Linux 1.7.0_75 / MacOSX JDK 1.7.0_71:

  • the current implementation is 2-3 times faster than the new conversion method

Linux 1.8.0_101:

  • the new conversion method is 50% faster than the the current implementation
  • the results of the current implementation are 2-3 times slower that the 1.7.0_75 results (KCMS/LCMS effect)

My special file is always way much faster with the new implementation.

Saying that it depends on the use case if it make sense to active the new conversion method or not.

What exactly are you doing? What JDK are you using?

I've got the following results on Linux for the attached pdf:

1.7.0_75: 4,8s vs. 12,9s (patched)
1.8.0_101: 8,8s vs. 5,8s (patched)

I can't see any unusual here, see my comment below

Ok, some more info. I'm on an Linux AMI instance on Amazon EC2, and on my Windows 7 desktop. Patch is slower on both. I'm using Oracle JRE 1.8.0_111. Not openjdk.

The code is kind of standard page rendering, from examples. This is a snippet of parts of the code, but I think it is clear enough:

PDDocument doc = PDDocument.load(pdfFile);
PDFRenderer renderer = new PDFRenderer(doc);
BufferedImage image = renderer.renderImageWithDPI(0, 110, ImageType.RGB);
image.flush();
doc.close();

Took another look and simplified my code to filter out only the code that is behaving slowly, which is the call to renderer.renderImage(). I edited the code snippet above also to remove unnecessary parts.

With patch it took 16 sec.
Without patch it took 2 sec.

Windows 7, jre1.8.0_91. Code is part of a web application run in Tomcat.

So, if the patch is faster on some platforms, it does not appear to benefit my application. Nor in the dev environment or on deployment in Linux. But since it is configurable between old/new functionality it is of no big concern for me. But I think it needs some investigation before deciding which option should be the default one.

I ran some additional tests on Linux and Win7 using oracle jdk1.8.0_111 with the following results in ascending order w.r.t. to the running time:

  • -Dsun.java2d.cmm=sun.java2d.cmm.kcms.KcmsServiceProvider (fastest appproach)
  • org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.UsePureJavaCMYKConversion
  • default
  • -Dsun.java2d.cmm=sun.java2d.cmm.kcms.KcmsServiceProvider and org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.UsePureJavaCMYKConversion (slowest approach)

That seems to concur with my findings yes. I had KcmsServiceProvider always on since it seems to be faster always, so my previous results where the extremes of your result list. I did some additional testing with Lcms and got the same results as you.

So what to learn? Kcms + UsePureJavaCMYKConversion is a no go always, or just for the Oracle JDK? Or just on Windows? Hmm.
Whats the benefit of this change if sun.java2d.cmm.kcms.KcmsServiceProvider is faster?
There are 1.8 jdks which don't provide the old KCMS, e.g. AIX. Maybe future versions of the jdk may not provide the fallback CMS anymore too.
